comments.commentBody: One child of Asian immigrants, one black man, one woman, check, check, check, diversity.  None of these people are qualified for the very important jobs they just got in government.  DeVos is anti-public schools now in charge of a public agency for education and is a mega-donor to the Republican party.  Carson is a surgeon now in charge of public housing and mortgage initiatives.  Haley has no foreign policy experience.  They have no qualifications and now are leading federal agencies, and serving as our voice in the UN, with employees that are more experience then their bosses.   But on the other hand, their boss has no experience in government, either.  How hard could it be, running a country?  The republicans have done a great job of convincing their constituents that no experience is not required.

Well, I personally think the election of Donald Trump is a disaster for the governance of our country and a sad commentary on the millions of "good" Americans desperate enough to vote for him.

That said, the editorial seems to be piling on by the editors. Trump is entitled to pick his diverse cabinet members, subject to the usual confirmations.

Ms Haley has just as much foreign policy making experience as Hillary Clinton had when President Obama named her as Secty of State.

Ms DeVos is one of many educated people who do not support Common Core, at least the way it has been implemented.

Mr Carson, well, that is a head scratcher for HUD; certainly he is no Henry Cisneros.

Regarding the right wing hard-liners, much as I hold most of them accountable for the botched war of ambition launched by GWB's administration, that's the prerogative of the president. As President Obama said, elections have consequences, especially for those who don't vote.

So much for his cabinet.

Perhaps the best that will be written of Mr Trump's presidency in future history books will be how good President Obama's tenure was by comparison. President Obama saved this country's economy from the disaster of republican economic policy, extracted us from wars of republican ambition, and demonstrated that intellect and reason should prevail over the cultural hatreds demonstrated by too many republicans.

Donald Trump has very big shoes to fill.

a disturbing thread running through trump's picks is that most of them are racists. bannon, sessions, flynn, and pompeo are haters, based on their past words and deeds. never before have people with clear contempt for millions of their fellow citizens been considered for these high offices which require sterling judgment, open mindedness, and a refusal to countenance irrational conspiracy theories in addition to  experience and basic competence. in that sense, trump's hires are shaping up to be a mirror of the man himself.

Thank you for the details. Having only been horrified (i.e., constantly experiencing the results of this election as a physical blow) that a person who wants to undermine the public school system as the Kochs, Cato Institute, etc., have been undermining public universities, I see your post as another confirmation of the web of money undermining our country.
According to Trump's criterion, he would choose a babysitter on the grounds that the person was once a baby.

The surprise should not be about the lack of experience of his appointments, but that Trump made any appointments at all.

Considering that Trump has boasted over the course of the campaign (and even before then) that he knows more about most things than anyone, why bother with advisers and cabinet appointments.

Some of the Trump boasts:

"I know more about ISIS (the Islamic State militant group) than the generals do. Believe me."

"I know more about foreign policy than anybody running."

"There is nobody who understands the horror of nuclear more than me."

"Nobody knows more about taxes than I do — maybe in the history of the world."

"I understand money better than anybody."

"Nobody knows jobs like I do."

"Nobody knows more about trade than me."

"I understand money better than anybody,"

Lastly, "Nobody reads the Bible more than me."

It seems that the NYT could not wrap up around a Trump's presidency. First he was not the right man, then he was incompetent, in the end he was labelled indecent ( to cite only one of the insults written by the columnists ).
And still, by some measure, the NYT expected mr. Trump, once he became president-elect, to turn around and change totally his mind.
And why should the voters have been elected such a flip-flopper?
It's a Trump's presidency, it has to reflect the Trump's views, of course. If one would have expected a different more-in-the-establishment cabinet, well, he or she didn't vote for the right candidate at the time.
But, in the NYT's newsroom echo chamber this doesn't resonate.
First mr. Trump appointed ideological people, now those without experience ( as if he came from a long way as first gentleman, senator and Secretary of State ). he's a man who continues to inspire "horrified" feelings according to the NYT, and all that as president-elect, that is he doesn't really put down a thing or two about policies.
Still, the NYT says he can't be trusted, he's not fooling anyone. But if history. which is the only topic one can pick with mr. Trump, is of any indication, the president-elect did substitute his campaign manager more than once and finally settled with a woman for the role. That and the fact it's two days the transcript of mr. Trump's interview at the NYT is top viewed speaks that right now it's the NYT to have a trust problem from which to recover.

"Change" for change's sake is foolishness. I have no problem with appointing highly qualified people who are new to government, provided they know the subject backwards and forwards. But people with no clue about it? That's idiocy.

Let me ask you this. Could someone replace you at your job, with no experience or training, and do a stellar job right out the door? Would you like someone who didn't know your field AT ALL appointed as your boss—just for the sake of change?

And how much more difficult is it to run a national department with so many moving parts?

Trump's appointments are sheer idiocy.

Hearing and reading the fawning and mincing praise heaped on President Obama's cabinet picks by the MSM in 2008 (basically lumping in his picks with FDR and JFK), I am laughing out loud at the criticism being heaped on President-Elect Trump for his picks. The other day they were hard-line old white men (code) and now when Trump foes in an other direction the picks get spun as inexperienced (more code).

Get over it MSM, there will be no apology tour this time. Free advice - try a little balance in your reporting before you become totally irrelevant.

Haley has been picked simply to make way for the Lt. Gov to take over, as payoff for being an early trump supporter.  Trump has no love lost for Haley, nor for the UN. They've done to Haley what Cheney died to Christy Whitman, sideline her!

If Trump had picked the usual DC establishment, the NYT would have been shouting from the rooftop that he was lying about "change."

If Trump had hired his entire Cabinet within a week, the NYT would have shouted that he was being "rash."

No wonder he is bypassing the MSM.

Trump's seemingly random selection of cabinet functionaries is telling the American public that his management policy will mirror  his TV show the Apprentice. where he could say.."You're Fired..." over and over again.

How many clowns can be stuffed in the Cabinet-mobile?  As a business owner, would he hire someone with ZERO experience on their CV for the job?  If not, why would he let these same people help run the United States?

Yet your headline says that Trump is adding diversity to his cabinet. He is not;  he is rewarding panderers. He hasn't a clue as to what he's doing. This is going to be government on the fly. Scary PB

Didn't Dr./Mr. Carson already indicate that he didn't think he was qualified to run Health and Human Services? I believe he was being honest. Now he's proposed something that seems more remote from his expertise. I hope he does the right thing and declines.

"[T]inkering with his stances...."? That's the understatement of the year! Trump has been swinging back and forth like a wrecking ball, from one extreme position to another. One day he's a populist, the next day he's part of the very establishment he railed against.

Your use of a phrase like "tinkering with his stances" only further enables this kind of erratic and unprincipled behavior. Please call it what it is which is a 180 degree reversal and a betrayal of his campaign promises to his supporters.

I suggest another criteria particularly for women: the look good factor. Both of Trumps female picks are strikingly good looking and Trump stated that one reason he liked Romney is that Romney looked the part.

I am truly speechless. Just when I thought it couldn't get worse, it did. Of course we still in suspense for SoS and SoD- but isn't that part of the game? Probably Mitt for SoS but his heart belongs to Rudy. Maybe Rudy for SoD- after all he was mayor during 9/11. Doesn't that qualify?

This is what our next four years will look like- unqualified people 'advising' an unqualified President. A Congress that will lock step behind him and a seat (or two if RBG can't hold out) in the Supreme Court.

This is all so depressing. (Guess I wasn't that speechless.)
